questions.question: What characterizes a malignant tumor?
options: It grows slowly and does not spread.
It is also called a benign tumor.
It can grow rapidly and spread to other parts of the body.

questions.question: Which type of childhood cancer accounts for about 28% of cases?
What is the most common type of leukemia in children?
In leukemia, what is a common range for the white blood cell count?
The highest incidence of leukemia occurs in children between what ages?
Which of the following is a clinical manifestation of leukemia?
In leukemia, leg or joint pain is caused by:
options: Destruction of the bone by leukemic cells

questions.question: What is a critical complication of leukemia?
Which of the following is part of the supportive treatment for leukemia?
What is stated as the leading cause of cancer-related death in children?
Which triad of symptoms commonly suggests a brain tumor due to CSF obstruction?
According to the symptom-location correlation table, recurrent early morning vomiting and head tilt are associated with a tumor in which location?
Which of the following is listed as a late effect from cancer therapy?
Wilms tumor is best described as:
options: A benign cyst of the liver
A cancer of the lymph nodes

questions.question: What is a critical nursing precaution for a child with a Wilms tumor?
options: Not to palpate the infant's abdomen.
Massage the abdomen gently to relieve pain.

questions.question: The primary treatment for Wilms tumor involves:
options: Surgery with possible x-ray irradiation and chemotherapy

questions.question: Hodgkin's disease primarily affects which system?
What is a common early clinical manifestation of Hodgkin's disease?
options: Painless enlargement of one or more cervical lymph nodes

questions.question: In Hodgkin's disease Stage I, the disease affects:
options: Lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm
Two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm
A single lymph node or extra lymphatic organ
Diffuse involvement of extra lymphatic organs

questions.question: What is a critical lifelong consideration if a total splenectomy is performed for Hodgkin's disease?
options: The child will need daily insulin.
Penicillin should be given daily for 1 to 2 years.
The child must avoid all physical activity.

questions.question: What is the purpose of follow-up care after childhood cancer treatment?
options: To only check if the cancer has come back.
To manage side effects, monitor health, and check for recurrence.
To immediately stop all previous medications.
To replace the need for a primary care doctor.

questions.question: Based on this presentation, what is the most probable diagnosis? (4-year-old with flank mass, fever, pink urine)
A 10-year-old with morning headaches, nausea, and clumsiness is most likely experiencing:
A 7-year-old with painless, rubbery enlarged lymph nodes, weight loss, and fatigue most likely has:
A 3-year-old with pallor, lethargy, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, and leg pain most likely has:
An adolescent with fatigue, bruising, infections, and many immature granulocytes likely has:
Which finding from a differential blood smear supports the diagnosis of ALL?
options: Presence of immature cells and anemia

questions.question: Why must blood flow be carefully regulated during transfusion for a leukemia patient?
options: To make the transfusion last longer.
To allow time to check for hemolysis.
To reduce the risk of fever.

questions.question: Which preoperative lab tests are required for a child with a brain tumor?
options: Complete Blood Count (CBC) and Coagulation studies

questions.question: Which manifestation is largely due to low platelet count in leukemia?
Which is an endocrinopathy late effect of brain tumor therapy?
What is the priority instruction for an infant with Wilms tumor?
options: Palpate deeply to determine the edges of the mass.
Avoid abdominal palpation to prevent potential metastasis.
Use percussion only to assess the size.
Ask the parents to show you where they feel the mass.

questions.question: What is a critical component of long-term management after splenectomy for Hodgkin's Disease?
options: Prophylactic antibiotic therapy such as penicillin daily for 1-2 years.

questions.question: Which nursing care is indicated for necrotic ulcerative perirectal lesions in leukemia?
options: Apply ice packs to the area.
Not measure temperature rectally and keep the area clean and dry.
Administer a high enema to clean the area.
Keep the area moist with petroleum jelly.

questions.question: Which investigation is crucial for suspected posterior fossa brain tumor?
options: MRI of the brain and spine

questions.question: Why is lifelong follow-up care required for childhood cancer survivors?
options: To immediately stop all cancer-related medications.
To only monitor for emotional problems.
To check that the cancer has not come back, manage side effects, and monitor overall health.

questions.question: Most of the time, there is a known cause for childhood cancers.
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) accounts for about 20% of all childhood leukemia.
The treatment for leukemia is considered curative, not palliative.
Brain tumours are the most common solid tumour in children.
For a child with a brain tumor, an abnormal neurological exam is uncommon.
Wilms tumor is commonly discovered in children between 6 months and 5 years of age.
In the early stages of Hodgkin's disease, the enlarged lymph nodes are typically painful.
A late effect of cancer therapy can include the development of a second, new cancer.
What is the most likely explanation for episodic abdominal pain in a child with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)?
options: It is a direct side effect of chemotherapy.
It is caused by gastric ulcers from stress.
It occurs owing to enlarged lymph nodes.
It results from severe constipation due to immobility.

questions.question: A 5-year-old with a brain tumor in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis is being assessed. Which symptoms should the nurse be most vigilant for?
options: Delayed puberty, anorexia, failure to thrive.

questions.question: Which hormone is specifically implicated if a pediatric brain tumor patient develops precocious puberty as a late effect of treatment?
Which symptom would be least likely classified as a direct late effect of prior cancer therapy in a childhood leukemia survivor?
options: Development of a new malignant brain tumor.
